moves.2. Nc3: Not a common move- we'll see why at the end.
moves.2... d5: I proceeded with the typical 2.d5 for black
moves.3. exd5 exd5: White, perhaps uncomfortable with the positions the French provides, opts for the clearer and more open Exchange Variation.
moves.4. d4 Bb4: This isn't exactly a book move for the Exchange Variation. But because the knight is here I'm developing my bishop a la Winawer. If he didn't block the pin, I probably would have exchanged the bishop for knight to double his pawns
moves.6. Qe2+: Brings the queen out early for a check. A useless move however. I get to develop a piece for free.
moves.6... Be6: Blocked behind the pawn but at least it's out.
moves.7... Nc6: ...useless check again. The knight threatens d4 once the queen moves away. White can't immediately move the d2 bishop to support the pawn, because I would capture the knight and double his pawns on the C file. However, with developing my knight, I left the b7 pawn undefended. I figured by this point I would capitalize on my advantage in development by gambitting the pawn and developing even more.
moves.8. Qxb7: He takes the gambit pawn. I'm curious as to what his best move was but I don't have an engine on hand
moves.8... Qe7: Developing the queen and setting up a discovery on white's King.
moves.10. Be2 Bxc6 11. O-O-O: Due to his lack of development by this point, he castles long to protect the king more quickly (especially with my queen out and his lack of one).
moves.11... O-O: Castle to activate and connect the rooks
moves.12. a3: White was sort of stuck here. If he developed his other knight, continues 12.Nf4? Bxc3 13. Bxc3 Qxe2. He also can't move his c3 knight anyway safely.
moves.12... Bxc3: I don't want to lose time to retreat so I just exchange here
moves.13. Bxc3: Bishop on C3 now blocks the C pawn and has no diagonal towards the center. Will have to move again to be useful, with the permanent pawns in the center.
moves.13... Ne4: Bringing the knight up the board
moves.14. Nh3: Blunder. This removes the defender of the Bishop on e2!
moves.14... Nxc3: Now we see the detriment of White's premature development of the Knight to c3. He blocked his C pawn which is normally useful in the Exchange variation.
moves.15. bxc3 Qxe2: White resigns. While the Exchange variation avoids the positional play typical of most French lines, it's easy for Black to crash through if White missteps.
